text: first part 350 million pounds that is
the growth sum that we send to the
European Union every week in fact it's
slightly more than that during the
course of the referendum campaign I made
it clear that we would end our
contribution to the European Union we
would take that money back we would
spend it on the people's priorities I
was asked about it in a number of public
interviews and a number of public stages
and I was always clear and consistent
that's the gross amount it takes account
of the rebec we can't count on the
rebate it also takes account of some of
the money that the European Union
currently spends in this country but
spends on priorities it sets not those
that we control we'll take that money
back we will control it ourselves
absolutely on the second point about the
campaign I don't retreat from anything
that I said in the campaign or anything
that I did in the campaign I was proud
to play a part in that campaign I
pondered I did my speech that it was a
wrench boy it was a wrench to part
company with the Prime Minister I've
known for so long and whom I admire so
much but as I hope I made clear in this
speech if you're a politician you're not
paid to tend to your own feelings you're
paid to lay out your beliefs and
convictions clearly and that's what I
did I was delighted that public voted to
leave the European Union and I believe
that whoever our next leader is should
be someone who argued for that mandate
believes in that mandate and can deliver
that mandate and on the final question
about Boris I worked with Boris during
the course of that referendum campaign
he campaigned with passion and briault
he was such a big part of it and
immediately after that I wanted to make
sure that someone who believed and as
Boris does in our destiny outside the
European Union could become Prime
Minister I didn't want that job for
myself but as I made clear during course
of the last week when we were trying to
build that team and we were trying to
ensure that Boris could become Prime
Minister it became clear to me and I
realized reluctantly but firmly that I
couldn't recommend that he should be
Prime Minister and it then fell to me to
stand myself
okay I think it's John the--another
ago spoke at all kindness and respect
it's very clear that Boris Johnson does
not have what it takes to be Prime
Minister does it's a resume and what it
takes to be Prime Minister and your
assassination of Boris Johnson but that
just cost you lots of kindness and
respect among your colleagues you'll
know that can you possibly recover well
two things
um I admire and respect all of the other
candidates in this leadership election
Theresa May has been an outstanding Home
Secretary if she's elected as prime
minister I'm sure she will do an
outstanding job but the one thing I want
to make clear is that I believe the
person who should be prime minister of
this country should be someone who
argued for and believes in the mandate
of the British people and Theresa
did not argue for and did not put the
case for Britain leaving the European
Union and that is a fundamental
divisional principle between the two of
us but I wouldn't take anything away
from Theresa's formidable qualities as a
front rank Minister on the second
question well as I pointed out in my
speech as education secretary and at
various different times in my career
people have sometimes said some less
than obliging things about me that is
something with which anyone who hopes to
lead has to live if you're the sort of
person who worries about personal
criticism if you're the sort of person
who allows the attacks from others to
get under your skin
you shouldn't be leader people can speak
out they can speak from their heart they
can say what they like about me but the
one thing that no one can say about me
is that I don't stand up and be counted
for my convictions when it matters and
yes sorry
yes well I've laid out a vision today
and I will lay out greater detail in
plans over the course of the next few
days and I'm asking people to look at my
track record of achievement in
government to look at my principles and
to look at my vision and to make their
judgment based on that because
ultimately when you're choosing a leader
when you're deciding who you want to put
the destiny of this country in the hands
of then the ultimate thing that matters
most is are they able to take tough and
sometimes very uncomfortable decisions
are they able to put sometimes you know
personal considerations aside to do what
is right above all do they have the
values the belief and the plan that will
leave this country effectively that is
the basis on which I'm standing the
basis on which I expect to be judged and
whatever the verdict I will respect it
